facts.text: Petition No. 13 of 1959 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging constitutional validity of s. 148-B of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 13 of 1959. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Harnam Singh and Sadhu Singh, for the petitioners. M. Sikri, Advocate-Gencral for the State of Punjab, Gopal Singh and D. Gupta, for respondent No. 1. 1959, April 1. The judgment-of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution in which the petitioners challenge the companystitutional validity of s. 148-B of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925  Punjab VIII of 1925 , hereinafter called the principal Act, the said section having been added to the principal Act by the Sikh Gurdwaras  Amendment  Act, 1959, hereinafter called the amending Act of 1959.

facts.text: Petitioners Harnam Singh and Sadhu Singh profess and practice the Sikh faith and are interested in maintenance and management of Sikh Gurdwaras.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners profess and practice the Sikh faith and they allege that they are interested in the maintenance and management of Sikh Gurdwaras, scheduled and numberified under the principal Act. Their main companytention is that s. 148-B violates the fundamental right granted under Art. 26 b  of the Constitution to every religious denomination or any section thereof including the Sikh denomination, to manage its own affairs in matters of religion .

facts.text: Respondents are State of Punjab and President and twelve members of Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala, deemed members under cl. (a) of sub-s. (1) of s. 148-B.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents to the petition are, firstly, the State of Punjab and, secondly,, President and twelve members of the Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala, who under cl.  a  of sub-s.  1  of s. 148-B shall be deemed to be members of the Board companystituted under s. 43 of the principal Act.

facts.text: Only State of Punjab contested the petition.

anchor.surface_text: The application has been companytested before us by respondent No. 1 only, namely, the State of Punjab, on the ground that s. 148-B does number, in any way, violate the fundamental right granted to the petitioners or other members of the Sikh denomination under Art. 26 b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Merger of State of Patiala and East Punjab States Union (PEPSU) with State of Punjab on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On November 1, 1956, there was merger of the erstwhile State of Patiala and the East Punjab States Union  hereafter called Pepsu in brief  with the State of Punjab.

facts.text: Government of Punjab appointed advisory committee in February 1957 to report on extending principal Act to former PEPSU area.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in February 1957 the Government of the State of Punjab appointed an advisory companymittee to report as to whether the principal Act should be extended to the area which was formerly within Pepsu.

facts.text: Advisory committee recommended extension of principal Act to former PEPSU area in September 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In September 1957 the companymittee recommended in favour of such extension.

facts.text: Sikh Gurdwaras Amendment Bill, 1958 introduced in Punjab Vidhan Sabha on April 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On April 8, 1958, a bill called the Sikh Gurdwaras  Amendment  Bill, 1958, was introduced in the Punjab Vidhan Sabha and the Bill was sent to the regional companymittees companystituted by an order of the President called the Punjab Regional Committees Order, 1957, made under el.  1  of Art. 371 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Annual election meeting of Sikh Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee in November 1958 resulted in majority by three votes for one group against Shiromani Akali Dal.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in November 1958 there was a meeting of the Sikh Gurdwara Prabandbak Com- mittee for the purpose of the annual election. Learned companynsel for the petitioners has stated before us that at this meeting there was a majority by a very small margin  three votes only  in favour of a particular group of Sikhs and against another group known as the Shiromoni Akali Dal.

facts.text: Notice given within one week after November 1958 election for meeting to consider amending Bill, but stayed by Judicial Commission.

anchor.surface_text: Within one week, however, a numberice was given for calling a meeting to companysider the provisions of the amending Bill this meeting companyld number, however, be held as an order of stay was obtained from the Judicial Commission companystituted under the principal Act.

facts.text: Special session of Vidhan Sabha summoned in December 1958 to consider amending Bill.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1958 a special session of the Vidhan Sabha was summoned to companysider the amending Bill.

facts.text: Regional committees submitted final report recommending addition of provisions becoming s.148-B on December 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Bill was accordingly sent back to the regional companymittees and on December 27, 1958, the regional companymittees submitted a final report and recommended the addition of provisions which subsequently became the provisions of s. 148-B of the principal Act.

facts.text: Amending Bill passed by Vidhan Sabha on December 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On December 31, 1958, the Bill was passed by the Vidhan Sabha, and on January 3, 1959, it was passed by the Legislative Council.

facts.text: Amending Bill passed by Legislative Council on January 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On December 31, 1958, the Bill was passed by the Vidhan Sabha, and on January 3, 1959, it was passed by the Legislative Council.

facts.text: Amending Act received assent of Governor on January 8, 1959, became Punjab Act No. 1 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On January 8, 1959, it received the assent of the Governor and became Punjab Act No. 1 of 1959, which is the Amending Act of 1959.

facts.text: Present petition filed on February 2, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1959, the present petition was filed and on February 14, 1959, the election of 35 Sikhs companytemplated under el.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s. 148-B was companypleted.

facts.text: Election of 35 Sikhs under cl. (b) of sub-s. (1) of s. 148-B completed on February 14, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1959, the present petition was filed and on February 14, 1959, the election of 35 Sikhs companytemplated under el.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s. 148-B was companypleted.

facts.text: Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala constituted by Punjab Government notification dated January 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: every person in the extended territories who, immediately before the companymencement of the Amending Act, is a member of the Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala, companystituted by Punjab Government, Home Department, Notification No. 18-Gurdwaras, dated the 10th January, 1958, shall be deemed to be a member of the Board, companystituted under section 43

facts.text: s. 148-B deems members of Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala as members of Board under s.43 and provides for election of 35 Sikhs from extended territories.

anchor.surface_text: S. 148-B.  1  As from the companymencement of the Amending Act, in addition to the members of the Board companystituted under section 43 and till the next election of the new Board under section 43-A-  a every person in the extended territories who, immediately before the companymencement of the Amending Act, is a member of the Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala, companystituted by Punjab Government, Home Department, Notification No. 18-Gurdwaras, dated the 10th January, 1958, shall be deemed to be a member of the Board, companystituted under section 43 and  b thirty-five Sikhs including six Sikhs belonging to the Scheduled Castes residents in the extended territories, to be divided among different districts thereof in proportion to the Sikh population of each district in the prescribed manner, who shall, within forty days of the companymencement of the Amending Act, be elected by the persons specified in subsection  2  in accordance with the rules made in this behalf by the State Government, shall become the members of the Board from the date specified in subsection  3 .

facts.text: Petitioners contend s.148-B violates Art. 26(b) fundamental right of Sikhs to manage own affairs in matters of religion.

anchor.surface_text: Their main companytention is that s. 148-B violates the fundamental right granted under Art. 26 b  of the Constitution to every religious denomination or any section thereof including the Sikh denomination, to manage its own affairs in matters of religion .

facts.text: Court holds s.148-B does not contravene Art. 26(b).

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the petitioners have failed to make out a case of violation of their fundamental right.

facts.text: Punjab Act No. 44 of 1953 amended s.43 of principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to the passing of Punjab Act No. 44 of 1953, s. 43 said that the Board shall companysist of  i  84 elected members,  ii  the bead ministers of certain well-known Sikh gurdwaras,  iii  12 members numberinated by the Rajpramukh of Pepsu and  iv  17 members resident in India of whom number more than four shall be residents in Punjab, companyopted by the members of the Board as described in  i ,  ii  and  iii  above. In 1953 was passed Punjab Act No. 44 of 1953 and s. 43 of the principal Act was amended.

facts.text: Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 passed for better administration of certain Sikh gurdwaras.

anchor.surface_text: and in 1925 the principal Act was passed, as its preamble states, for the better administration of certain Sikh gurdwaras and for enquiries into matters and settlement of disputes companynected therewith .

facts.text: Provisions of s.148-B are temporary and transitional under Chapter XII-A.

anchor.surface_text: It is worthy of numbere here that s. 148-B occurs in chapter XII-A and the heading of the chapter is Temporary and Transitional Provisions which indicates clearly enough that the provisions in sections 148-B to 148-F ate temporary and transitional provisions.
Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution

Their main contention is that s. 148-B violates the fundamental right granted under Art. 26 b  of the Constitution to every religious denomination or any section thereof including the Sikh denomination, to manage its own affairs in matters of religion .

anchor.surface_text: S. 148-B.  1  As from the commencement of the Amending Act, in addition to the members of the Board constituted under section 43 and till the next election of the new Board under section 43-A-  a every person in the extended territories who, immediately before the commencement of the Amending Act, is a member of the Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala, constituted by Punjab Government, Home Department, Notification No. 18-Gurdwaras, dated the 10th January, 1958, shall be deemed to be a member of the Board, constituted under section 43 and  b thirty-five Sikhs including six Sikhs belonging to the Scheduled Castes residents in the extended territories, to be divided among different districts thereof in proportion to the Sikh population of each district in the prescribed manner, who shall, within forty days of the commencement of the Amending Act, be elected by the persons specified in subsection  2  in accordance with the rules made in this behalf by the State Government, shall become the members of the Board from the date specified in subsection  3 .

concepts.interpretation: Temporary and transitional provision for interim representation from extended territories (PEPSU); does not interfere with matters of religion under Art. 26(b).

anchor.surface_text: The application has been contested before us by respondent No. 1 only, namely, the State of Punjab, on the ground that s. 148-B does not, in any way, violate the fundamental right granted to the petitioners or other members of the Sikh denomination under Art. 26 b  of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Undue haste in enacting amending Act to favor particular group after election loss violates fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners has first commented on what he has characterised as undue haste in passing the amending Act of 1959. He has submitted that the Pepsu area came within the State of Punjab in November, 1956, and for about two years, the Punjab Government evinced no serious anxiety to extend the principal Act to that area but from November 16, 1958,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , it has a duty to ensure proper observance of all essential religious ceremonies of the Sikh faith, which according to him is a I matter of religion.

arguments.court_reasoning: Court cannot inquire into legislative motives or political wisdom unless fundamental right violated

arguments.claim: Art.26(b) requires direct election by entire Sikh community to manage gurdwaras as matter of religion
arguments.court_reasoning: No textual support in Sikh religion or Act; confuses religion with politics; historical provisions allow nomination/co-option

arguments.claim: Members of Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala are government nominees, not representative, not subject to ss.45/46 disqualifications, violating Art.26(b)
arguments.court_reasoning: Interim designation for convenience; historical precedents for nomination; no suggested disqualifications

arguments.claim: Electorate under s.148-B(2) for 35 Sikhs not representative: elected by mixed constituencies, government influenced, violating Art.26(b)
arguments.court_reasoning: Method dictated by convenience for interim; all electors Sikhs; remote influence insufficient for violation

arguments.court_reasoning: Limits powers to property when read together

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners has emphasised that part of the section which relates to proper observance of all ceremonies and religious observances and has contended that as the Board is the committee in respect of some of the principal gurdwaras, it has a duty to ensure proper observance of all essential religious ceremonies of the Sikh faith, which according to him is a matter of religion. Under s. 134, the Committee has power inter alia to dismiss an office-holder or minister,

arguments.court_reasoning: Court assumes arguendo but decides on narrower ground that s.148-B does not affect these powers

arguments.claim: Art.26(b) and (d) distinguished: (b) absolute for matters of religion (essential rites); (d) subject to law for property

anchor.surface_text: Article 26 of the Constitution, so far as it is relevant for our purpose, says- Art. 26. Subject to public order, morality and health, every religious denomination or any section thereof shall have the right a  b to manage its own affairs in matters of religion d to administer such property in accordance with law. The distinction between cls. b and d strikes one at once.

arguments.claim: 'Matters of religion' under Art.26(b) limited to essential religious practices/rites, not administrative election

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 26 b , a religious denomination or Organisation enjoys complete autonomy in the matter of deciding as to what rites and ceremonies are essential according to the tenets of the religion they hold  we emphasise here the word essential .

arguments.claim: s.148-B relates to property administration under Art.26(d), not matters of religion under 26(b)

anchor.surface_text: Two questions, therefore, arise in connection with the argument of learned counsel for the petitioners 1 does s. 148-B added to the principal Act by the amending Act of 1959 have reference only to administration of property of Sikh gurdwaras and, therefore, must be judged by cl. d of Art. 26

arguments.claim: s.148-B does not interfere with matters of religion; temporary representation for extended areas by convenience
Historical context of Act shows Board constitution includes election, nomination, co-option, designation; s.148-B consistent
Court cannot inquire into legislative motives absent fundamental rights violation

anchor.surface_text: whatever justification some people may feel in their criticisms of the political wisdom of a particular legislative or executive action, this Court cannot be called upon to embark on an enquiry into public policy or investigate into questions of political wisdom or even to pronounce upon motives of the legislature in enacting a law which it is otherwise competent to make.

holdings.text: s. 148-B of the principal Act does not contravene the fundamental right granted to the Sikhs under Art. 26(b) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the petitioners have failed to make out a case of violation of their fundamental right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.148-B is temporary transitional provision for interim Board representation from extended PEPSU territories; concerns property administration under Art.26(d) subject to law, not essential religious practices or rites under Art.26(b); method of election/ designation not part of Sikh religion

holdings.text: s. 148-B has reference only to administration of property of Sikh gurdwaras and must be judged by cl. (d) of Art. 26

anchor.surface_text: Two questions, therefore, arise in connection with the argument of learned counsel for the petitioners 1 does s. 148-B added to the principal Act by the amending Act of 1959 have reference only to administration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board powers under ss.125,129 (read harmoniously) limited to property control/superintendence; Act preamble for better gurdwara administration; distinguished from religious matters

holdings.text: s. 148-B does not affect matters of religion within the meaning of cl. (b) of Art. 26

anchor.surface_text: of property of Sikh gurdwaras and, therefore, must be judged by cl. d of Art. 26 or 2 does it affect matters of religion within the meaning of cl. b of the said Article ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Matters of religion' limited to essential rites/practices per Shirur Mutt; s.148-B only adds interim members without altering Board's powers under ss.133/134

holdings.text: s. 148-B does not interfere in matters of religion
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.148-B does not affect Board's/Committee's powers under ss.133/134; only interim membership addition; assumes arguendo other provisions may relate to religion but irrelevant

holdings.text: a direct election of the members of the Board by the entire Sikh community is not itself a matter of the Sikh religion
holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual/religious authority supports; historical Act provisions include nomination/designation/co-option; confuses religion with politics/democracy

holdings.text: the designation of members of the Interim Gurdwara Board, Patiala, as an interim measure to represent Pepsu gurdwaras is not violative of any fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the designation of such members, as an interim measure, to represent those gurdwaras in the Pepsu area which they were actually managing is violative of any fundamental right

holdings.reasoning_summary: Convenience for transitional period; consistent with prior nomination provisions; no disqualifications alleged under ss.45/46

holdings.text: the electorate detailed in sub-s. (2) of s. 148-B does not constitute an infringement of the right of the Sikhs under Art. 26(b)
holdings.reasoning_summary: All electors Sikhs; indirect/mixed constituency remote; govt influence speculative; interim convenience; minority representation

holdings.text: Courts cannot inquire into legislative motives, public policy or political wisdom unless a fundamental right is violated

anchor.surface_text: whatever justification some people may feel in their criticisms of the political wisdom of a particular legislative or executive action, this Court cannot be called upon to embark on an enquiry into public policy or investigate into questions of political wisdom or even to pronounce upon motives of the legislature in enacting a law which it is otherwise competent to make.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited judicial review function; applies to haste/mala fides claim absent rights violation

precedents.citation: The COmmissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1

anchor.surface_text: The COmmissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt 1

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between cl. (b) and cl. (d) of Art. 26: administration of property subject to law, but managing own affairs in matters of religion as fundamental right not to be taken away by legislature
precedents.cited_holding: The administration of its property by a religious denomination has thus been placed on a different footing from the right to manage its own affairs in matter of religion. The latter is a fundamental right which no legislature can take away, whereas the former can be regulated by laws which the legislature can validly impose.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents.cited_proposition: Under Art. 26(b), religious denomination enjoys complete autonomy in deciding essential rites and ceremonies
precedents.cited_holding: under Art. 26 b , a religious denomination or Organisation enjoys complete autonomy in the matter of deciding as to what rites and ceremonies are essential according to the tenets of the religion they hold

precedents.cited_proposition: Matters of religion in Art. 26(b) include practices regarded by the community as part of its religion; emphasis on essential practices
precedents.cited_holding: matters of religion in Art. 26 b  include practices which are regarded by the community as part of its religion
